Articles.Content:
How do you calculate...

...Eccentricity of an orbit?

...The geostationary orbit of a planet?

...The dV of a perfect Hohmann transfer?

Edited October 29, 2013 by KvickFlygarn87
Answered

The wiki here and wikipedia are your best friend for questions such as these. Try:-

http://wiki.kerbalspaceprogram.com/wiki/Orbit

http://wiki.kerbalspaceprogram.com/wiki/KEO

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geostationary_orbit

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hohmann_transfer_orbit
Ah, thanks. I should've googled a bit before asking.

This link has some pretty good information as well

http://www.braeunig.us/space/orbmech.htm

dV:

- Transfer Calculator: http://ksp.olex.biz/

- Launch Window Planner: http://alexmoon.github.io/ksp/

Both of them provide the dV of a 'perfect' transfer, but the window planner tells you exactly when to do the transfer. If you combine the information given by both of them you can work out how much dV you will need, when to begin the transfer and where you need to be in relation to the body you are currently orbiting.

The other two things are calculated fairly easily and the information for that has already been linked. All eccentricity and geosynchronous values can be found on the KSP wiki for each planet (where applicable) along with a lot of other most irrelevant but very interesting numbers.
